The correct answers to this question are C, D, and E:

C. Operating system: IaaS provides virtualized infrastructure, including servers, storage, and networking, on top of which customers can deploy and manage their own applications and operating systems.

D. Servers and storage: IaaS provides virtualized servers and storage, which can be provisioned and scaled up or down on demand.

E. Firewall and network security: IaaS provides network security features, such as firewall and virtual private network (VPN) capabilities, to secure the infrastructure and the applications that run on it.

A and B are not part of IaaS:

A. Business analytics: Business analytics is not a feature of IaaS. It is a separate area of functionality that may be provided by other cloud services, such as Software as a Service (SaaS) or Platform as a Service (PaaS).

B. Real-time monitoring: Real-time monitoring is not a feature of IaaS itself. It is a monitoring capability that can be added on top of IaaS through third-party tools or services.

C. Operating System: IaaS provides the ability to deploy and manage operating systems on virtual machines, giving users full control over the operating system and the applications that run on it.

D. Servers and Storage: IaaS provides access to virtualized servers and storage, allowing users to easily provision and scale resources as needed.

E. Firewall and Network Security: IaaS provides network security features, such as firewalls, to help protect resources from unauthorized access and other security threats.

The three features that are part of Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) are:

C. Operating system: With IaaS, the cloud provider offers virtualized infrastructure, including servers, storage, and networking components, while the customer is responsible for managing the operating system, middleware, and applications.

D. Servers and storage: IaaS provides virtualized servers and storage, allowing customers to rapidly scale up or down depending on their needs.

E. Firewall and network security: IaaS providers typically offer built-in firewall and network security capabilities, allowing customers to secure their virtual infrastructure without having to manage physical security appliances.

Business analytics and real-time monitoring are not typically part of IaaS offerings, but may be offered as separate services or may be part of other cloud service models, such as Platform as a Service (PaaS) or Software as a Service (SaaS).
